title: 105_hr3157
content: The "Teachers in the Classroom Act" may be cited as the short title of this Act. The findings section follows the short title. Congress finds that enrollment in elementary and secondary schools is at record levels, with an expected increase of over a million students in 1998. The increase in student enrollment will continue for the next decade, with more than 3 million additional students expected. This growth will impact high poverty urban and rural areas, as well as states with rapid population growth. Schools will need to expand to accommodate the growing number of students. To keep up with the rising student enrollment, schools will need to hire 150,000 more teachers in the next decade. Research shows that students in smaller classes in the early grades learn more and maintain an academic advantage even after returning to normal-sized classrooms. Adding students to a classroom diminishes learning for the rest of the class. Research shows that students in smaller classes learn more and maintain an academic edge over their peers even after returning to normal-sized classrooms. It is important to adequately educate and prepare America's children for the future, improve the learning environment, hire new teachers, and provide resources to keep pace with growing enrollment. Congress should fund teacher positions without increasing the Federal bureaucracy, deficit, or debt. SEC. 3. GRANT PROGRAM. The Secretary of Education can award grants to Governors for hiring teachers to reduce overcrowded classes. Governors must apply to the Secretary to be eligible for the grant. Local educational agencies must establish a trust fund and provide assurances to receive funds from the Governor. Local educational agencies must establish a trust fund for payments received under the Act, deposit funds in the trust account, use funds to hire new teachers or personnel within 2 years, follow accounting practices set by the Governor, and increase the number of teachers or instructional personnel in classrooms. The agency must provide access to records of funds received and used under the Act, ensure a net gain in teachers or instructional personnel, review personnel performance annually, limit employment period to one year, repay unused funds to the State within 27 months, and use funds to supplement non-Federal sources. The agency must ensure a net gain in teachers, limit employment period to one year, repay unused funds within 27 months, and apply to the Governor annually for funding under this Act. SEC. 4. DISTRIBUTION OF FUNDS. Each State receives funds based on the number of children aged 5-17. Unused funds are reallocated to other States. SEC. 5. FISCAL REQUIREMENTS. The agency must ensure a net gain in teachers, limit employment period to one year, repay unused funds within 27 months, and apply for funding annually. SEC. 5. FISCAL REQUIREMENTS. A Governor can withhold payments to a local educational agency for noncompliance with section 3(c) after 60 days notice. The agency must increase teachers or personnel to continue receiving funds. A Governor receiving a grant under this Act must select local educational agencies based on the need to alleviate overcrowded classes. They must evaluate and report on the funds used by the agencies annually, with a limit of 2 percent for administrative costs. Governors can also use funds for innovative teaching programs. The Secretary of Education can use up to 2 percent of funds for administrative costs and up to 10 percent for innovative teaching programs. The Secretary must report annually to Congress on the use of funds. The Secretary of Education, in consultation with the Governors, must report annually to Congress on the effectiveness of programs assisted under this Act and provide recommendations for program continuity by March 1 each year. SEC. 7. CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not provide tenure to personnel hired under it. SEC. 8. DEFINITION. Defines "local educational agency," "State," and "Secretary." SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization of appropriations for the Act are as follows: $500,000,000 for fiscal year 1999, $1,000,000,000 for fiscal year 2000, $1,500,000,000 for fiscal year 2001, $2,000,000,000 for fiscal year 2002, and $2,500,000,000 for fiscal year 2003.
